wiki_summary_en : Fort 50 ½ O Kosocice – one of the forts of the Kraków Fortress. It was built between 1897 and 1899. In 1945, it was stripped of its towers – both armored and observation. It belonged to the VII fortified area. The object was designed by Emil Gołogórski. 

It defended the railway line to Przemyśl and the Lwów Route. In December 1914, the fort, along with the neighboring forts 50 "Prokocim" and 51 "Rajsko," held back the main force of the Russian assault on Kraków. The fort is in good condition and is occasionally open to visitors. It is part of the Kraków Fortress Museum. The object is located at J. Hallera Street in Kraków.

wiki_summary_en : Kraków Zabłocie – a train station in Kraków, in the Podgórze district, in its formerly industrial part, Zabłocie. It was opened in 1979. Only passenger trains stop at the station. The station can be accessed via Kącik Street (from the Old Podgórze side) and Lipowa Street (from the Zabłocie side).

wiki_summary_en : Kraków Sanktuarium – a passenger stop in the Kraków Łagiewniki area, in the Małopolskie Voivodeship, built to serve the Kraków sanctuaries: the Sanctuary of Divine Mercy and the John Paul II Center, a shopping center on Zakopiańska Street, and nearby residential buildings during the World Youth Days 2016 and for the needs of the Fast Urban Railway.

wiki_summary_en : Kowadza (261 m) – a hill in Tyniec in Kraków. Administratively, it belongs to District VIII Dębniki. Geographically, it is part of the Tyniec Hills on the Kraków Bridge within the macroregion of the Kraków Gate. These hills have been included in the area of the Bielańsko-Tyniecki Landscape Park.  
Kowadza rises on the eastern side of Świętojańska Street in Tyniec. Formed from limestone, the hill is mostly covered by a beech-hornbeam forest, but the summit and southern slopes are open fields of former pastures and meadows. It is covered by a thin layer of soil with xerothermic grassland. Thanks to the open areas, the summit of Kowadza is a good viewpoint. In the valley lies Uroczysko Tyniec, to the southwest the horizon is obscured by the hills of Wielkanoc and Bogucianka, to the south Guminek, and just to the east is the hill Duża Kowodrza.  
An ecological site named Uroczysko Kowadza, covering an area of 10 ha, has been established on Kowadza. Benches, trash bins, tourist information boards, and a shelter have been prepared for tourists. A marked hiking trail runs over the summit of Kowadza, with educational paths along its slopes.

answer:
**Good Lood** (the ice cream shop) has **three locations in Kraków**, each with slightly different opening hours on **Saturdays**. Based on the context data, here’s the relevant information for your question:

### **Good Lood Opening Hours on Saturdays**:
1. **Tadeusza Romanowicza Street** (Podgórze/Zabłocie area)
   - **Hours**: **11:00–21:00** (Mo–Su)
   - *Note*: Same hours every day, including Saturdays.
   - 📍 [Map Location](https://www.google.com/maps/place/50.0475033,19.9640347)
   - 🍦 Takeaway: **Yes** | 🦽 Wheelchair: **Yes**

2. **Bolesława Orlińskiego Street** (Near Kraków Airport/Balice)
   - **Hours**: **10:00–21:00** (Sa–Su)
   - *Note*: Opens earlier on weekends (10 AM vs. 11 AM on weekdays).
   - 📍 [Map Location](https://www.google.com/maps/place/50.0817384,19.9996506)
   - 🍦 Takeaway: **No** | 🦽 Wheelchair: **Yes**

3. **Aleja Pułkownika Beliny-Prażmowskiego** (Near Blonia Park)
   - **Hours**: **11:00–21:00** (Saturday)
   - *Note*: Closes 30 mins earlier on weekdays (Mon–Fri until 20:30).
   - 📍 [Map Location](https://www.google.com/maps/place/50.0686213,19.9597106)
   - 🍦 Takeaway: **Yes** | 🦽 Wheelchair: **No**

---
### **Recommendation**:
- If you’re near **Podgórze/Zabłocie** (e.g., visiting Schindler’s Factory or MOCAK), the **Romanowicza location** is open until 9 PM.
- For **early access (10 AM)**, head to the **Orlińskiego** spot (near the airport).
- The **Beliny-Prażmowskiego** location (close to the city center) is ideal if you’re exploring **Blonia Park** or **Wawel**.

💡 **Pro Tip**: Check their [website](https://goodlood.com) for seasonal updates or special events! Their artisanal ice cream (with vegan options) is a must-try in Kraków.
